entry.et: Middle English, from Middle French or Latin; Middle French adopter, from Latin adoptare, from ad- + optare to choose

def.dt: :to take by choice into a relationship
:to take voluntarily (a child of other parents) as one's own child
:to take up and practice or use adopted a moderate tone
:to accept formally and put into effect adopt a constitutional amendment
:to choose (a textbook) for required study in a course
:to sponsor the care and maintenance of adopt a highway
:to adopt a child couples choosing to adopt

entry.pt: adopt embrace espouse mean to take an opinion, policy, or practice as one's own. adopt implies accepting something created by another or foreign to one's nature forced to adopt new policies. embrace implies a ready or happy acceptance embraced the customs of their new homeland. espouse adds an implication of close attachment to a cause and a sharing of its fortunes espoused the cause of women's rights.
